Articles.Content:
This is not a challenge about how fast you make your spacecraft go, or how quickly you can get a mission done in game time. This is about how quickly you can play KSP in actual, real, minutes-of-your-human-life-on-Earth time. This is a physical, pound-the-keyboard, arcade race.

Looking for a quick challenge? This is definitely it! Design a craft from scratch, fly it to the Mun, plant a flag on the Mun, and then bring the crew home alive again as fast as you can. That's it! Fastest real-life time to complete the mission wins.

RULES:

1. You are free to use stock time-warp and physics warp as much as you like. (But no use of non-stock warp settings.) So if you can handle a launch at 4x physics warp, go for it!

2. Your time includes the time to build your craft in the VAB/SPH. No loading from a file (although of course you can memorize how you're going to build it and simply construct it from memory). So build quickly!

3. Timer starts when the first part is placed in your build and ends when you hit "Recover Vessel" at the end of your mission.

4. The no unfair advantages rule: Don't cheat and don't use mods that convey a material advantage over stock. Declare any parts or performance mods you use. The rule of thumb here is: If your run could have been done almost the same without mods, it's probably OK. FAR is OK although if people get super-competitive (top times differing by only a few seconds), I may split it into FAR and non-FAR divisions. (I figure for the best runs, FAR gives maybe a one- or two-second advantage.)

5. No MechJeb or Kerbal Alarm Clock. It's your piloting skills and your time-management skills. If you overshoot your periapsis burn because you're set to 100,000 warp, too bad.

6. A full video is required in order to document the actual time taken. No cheating, speeding up the video, or editing the video for length (although you may add a soundtrack and commentary afterward if you like). Note: If someone can come up with another foolproof way to measure elapsed actual time that doesn't require video, I'm open to suggestions. I realize video is limiting to many people.

7. Crew death = disqualification.

That's it! Let me know if I missed anything.

(Note: This challenge is inherently possible. I've been to the Mun many times, just not very quickly.)

This is definitely a good challenge but you should not count loading times towards the total time because that will give people with slower computers (i.e: me) a major disadvantage while people with Scott Manly computers will have a huge advantage, also when the time in the top left corner is yellow it means that the game is slowing down time to let physics catch up with the game which adds real world time that the user cannot control. fix these two things and this will be a fantastic challenge!

These are both legitimate concerns, but coming up with a workable solution could be tough because it would require accurately measuring the amount of time slowdown. I think the best solution is just to run a lower screen resolution and use low graphics detail settings -- only for the duration of your attempt, of course.

Also, for most winning entries I would imagine the part count will be low and that should help keep the game running smoothly. Lots of parts would simply take too long to build! :-)

PS: I like the Lego flag, BTW. Reminds me of my childhood!
